 Almost 30 years ago, I used to run an oxidation/corrosion test on oils and hydraulic fluid. Air was bubbled through the fluid which had Cu, Zn, Fe, Cd and Al coupons in it. After 1 week at 250F, with air being bubbled continuously through the oil, most oils and hydraulic fluids blacked, increased in viscosity and acidity and began attacking the corrosion coupons. Mobil 1 came out of the test almost exactly as it went in. No viscosity change, no corrosion, no acidity increase. I've use only synthetics since that day for every vehicle that I've owned and some of those that I leased. emoticon_xgood

I change oil every 5000 miles if I remember. 6000-7000 if I don't
 
 My father used to be the fire chief of a fairly sized town. They had enough vehicles in their fleet, and enough miles being put on, to make some oil analysis cost effective. They chose 10 vehicles from the fleet and sent in the oil for analysis every 1000 miles. Most of them needed an oil change at about 8500 miles. 2 of them made it to 10,000 miles. These were not vehicles that were used particularly lightly.
 
 Back in the old days when we used non multi weight, non detergent oils, 3000 miles was a good interval. Those days are gone.
 
 When your oil gets dark, it means nothing. That is the result of minute particles fo soot in the oil. Back in the old days, those particles woudl not be suspended in the oil. Rather they would end up as that nasty sludge that you have to scrape off when you rebuild old engines. In those days, when your oil was dark, you had certainly waited too long. Today, dark oil just means that the oil is doing its job breaking down soot and transporting it as opposed to letting it sludge up your engine. 
 
 Strangely enough, there is a whole page about nothign but changing your oil at http://www.nordicgroup.us/oil.htm#The%203000%20Mile%20Myth that has some interesting tidbits (I was searching for why jiffy lubs sucks when I found it).
